Article.ArticleTitle: A putatively new family of alphaproteobacterial chloromethane degraders from a deciduous forest soil revealed by stable isotope probing and metagenomics.

AbstractText: Chloromethane (CH<sub>3</sub>Cl) is the most abundant halogenated organic compound in the atmosphere and substantially responsible for the destruction of the stratospheric ozone layer. Since anthropogenic CH<sub>3</sub>Cl sources have become negligible with the application of the Montreal Protocol (1987), natural sources, such as vegetation and soils, have increased proportionally in the global budget. CH<sub>3</sub>Cl-degrading methylotrophs occurring in soils might be an important and overlooked sink.

The objective of our study was to link the biotic CH<sub>3</sub>Cl sink with the identity of active microorganisms and their biochemical pathways for CH<sub>3</sub>Cl degradation in a deciduous forest soil. When tested in laboratory microcosms, biological CH<sub>3</sub>Cl consumption occurred in leaf litter, senescent leaves, and organic and mineral soil horizons. Highest consumption rates, around 2 mmol CH<sub>3</sub>Cl g<sup>-1</sup> dry weight h<sup>-1</sup>, were measured in organic soil and senescent leaves, suggesting that top soil layers are active (micro-)biological CH<sub>3</sub>Cl degradation compartments of forest ecosystems. The DNA of these [<sup>13</sup>C]-CH<sub>3</sub>Cl-degrading microbial communities was labelled using stable isotope probing (SIP), and the corresponding taxa and their metabolic pathways studied using high-throughput metagenomics sequencing analysis. [<sup>13</sup>C]-labelled Metagenome-Assembled Genome closely related to the family Beijerinckiaceae may represent a new methylotroph family of Alphaproteobacteria, which is found in metagenome databases of forest soils samples worldwide. Gene markers of the only known pathway for aerobic CH<sub>3</sub>Cl degradation, via the methyltransferase system encoded by the CH<sub>3</sub>Cl utilisation genes (cmu), were undetected in the DNA-SIP metagenome data, suggesting that biological CH<sub>3</sub>Cl sink in this deciduous forest soil operates by a cmu-independent metabolism.
